description: From Middle English counseil, conseil, from Old French conseil, from Latin cōnsilium; akin to cōnsulō (“take counsel, consult”).

entries.meaning: The exchange of opinions and advice especially in legal issues; consultation.

examples: It was ill counsel had misled the girl.

entries.meaning: Deliberate purpose; design; intent; scheme; plan.
A lawyer, as in King's Counsel (KC) or Queen's Counsel (QC).

verbs.description: counsel (third-person singular simple present counsels, present participle counselling or counseling, simple past and past participle counselled or counseled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give advice, especially professional advice, to (somebody).
examples: The lawyer counselled his client to remain silent.
Psychiatrists, psychologists, social workers and other mental health professionals counsel clients.
I would counsel prudence in this matter.
